Until 1 March 1923, Greece used the [[Julian calendar]], in which the date is 28 May 1921.|group=fn}} is the husband and [[Prince consort|consort]] of [[Queen Elizabeth II]]. Philip was born into the [[Greek royal family|Greek]] and [[Danish royal family|Danish royal families]]. He was born in [[Greece]], but his family was exiled from the country when he was an infant. After being educated in [[France]], [[Germany]], and the [[United Kingdom]], he joined the British [[Royal Navy]] in 1939, aged 18. From July 1939, he began corresponding with the 13-year-old Princess Elizabeth, whom he had first met in 1934. During the [[Second World War]] he served with distinction in the [[Mediterranean Fleet|Mediterranean]] and [[British Pacific Fleet|Pacific]] Fleets. After the war, Philip was granted permission by [[King George VI]] to marry Elizabeth. Before the official announcement of their engagement in July 1947, he abandoned his Greek and Danish royal titles and became a naturalised [[British subject]], adopting the surname [[Mountbatten family|Mountbatten]] from his maternal grandparents. He [[Wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Philip Mountbatten|married Elizabeth]] on 20 November 1947. Just before the wedding, he was created [[Baron Greenwich]], [[Earl of Merioneth]] and [[Duke of Edinburgh]]. Philip left active military service when Elizabeth became monarch in 1952, having reached the rank of [[commander (Royal Navy)|commander]], and was formally made a [[British prince]] in 1957. Prince Philip and Queen Elizabeth II have four children: [[Prince Charles]], [[Princess Anne]], [[Prince Andrew]], and [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex|Prince Edward]]. Through a British [[Order in Council]] issued in 1960, descendants of Philip and Elizabeth not bearing royal styles and titles can use the surname [[Mountbatten-Windsor]], which has also been used by some members of the royal family who do hold titles, such as Prince Andrew, Princess Anne and Prince Edward. A keen sports enthusiast, Philip helped develop the equestrian event of [[carriage driving]]. He is a patron, president or member of over 780 organisations and serves as chairman of [[The Duke of Edinburgh's Award]] for people aged 14 to 24. He is the longest-serving consort of a reigning British monarch and the oldest-ever male member of the [[British royal family]]. Philip retired from his royal duties on 2 August 2017, at the age of 96, after having completed 22,219 solo engagements since 1952. ==Early life== [[File:Corfu Mon Repos R01.jpg|left|thumb|[[Mon Repos, Corfu|Mon Repos]], the birthplace of Philip]] Prince Philip of Greece and Denmark was born in [[Mon Repos, Corfu|Mon Repos]] on the Greek island of [[Corfu]] on 10 June 1921, the only son and fifth and final child of [[Prince Andrew of Greece and Denmark]] and [[Princess Alice of Battenberg]].Brandreth, p. 56 Philip's four elder sisters were [[Princess Margarita of Greece and Denmark|Margarita]], [[Princess Theodora of Greece and Denmark (1906–1969)|Theodora]], [[Princess Cecilie of Greece and Denmark|Cecilie]], and [[Princess Sophie of Greece and Denmark|Sophie]]. He was baptised into the [[Greek Orthodox Church]]. His godparents were his paternal grandmother [[Queen Olga of Greece]] and Alexandros S. Kokotos, Mayor of Corfu.{{cite web|url=http://users.uniserve.com/~canyon/christenings.htm#Christenings|title=Yvonne's Royalty Home Page: Royal Christenings|website=users.uniserve.com|accessdate=23 May 2018}} Shortly after Philip's birth, his maternal grandfather, [[Prince Louis of Battenberg]], then known as Louis Mountbatten, [[Marquess of Milford Haven]], died in London. Louis was a naturalised British citizen, who, after a career in the [[Royal Navy]], had renounced his German titles and adopted the surname [[Mountbatten family|Mountbatten]], an Anglicized version of [[Battenberg family|Battenberg]], during the First World War due to [[Anti-German sentiment#First World War#Great Britain|Anti-German sentiment]] in Great Britain. After visiting London for the memorial, Philip and his mother returned to Greece where Prince Andrew had remained behind to command an army division embroiled in the [[Greco-Turkish War (1919–1922)]].Brandreth, pp. 58–59 The war went badly for Greece, and the Turks made large gains. On 22 September 1922, Philip's uncle, [[Constantine I of Greece|King Constantine I]], was forced to abdicate and the new military government arrested Prince Andrew, along with others. The commander of the army, General [[Georgios Hatzianestis]], and five senior [[Trial of the Six|politicians were executed]]. Prince Andrew's life was believed to be in danger, and Alice was under surveillance. In December, a revolutionary court banished Prince Andrew from Greece for life.{{citation|title=News in Brief: Prince Andrew's Departure|journal=The Times|date=5 December 1922|page=12}} The British naval vessel [[HMS Calypso (D61)|HMS ''Calypso'']] evacuated Prince Andrew's family, with Philip carried to safety in a cot made from a fruit box. Philip's family went to France, where they settled in the Paris suburb of [[Saint-Cloud]] in a house lent to them by his wealthy aunt, [[Princess George of Greece and Denmark]].Alexandra, pp. 35–37; Heald, p. 31; Vickers, pp. 176–178 Because Philip left Greece as a baby, he does not have a strong grasp of the [[Greek language]]. In 1992, he said that he "could understand a certain amount".{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/a-strange-life-profile-of-prince-philip-1563268.html |work=The Independent |location=London | title=A strange life: Profile of Prince Philip | first=Fiammetta | last=Rocco | date=13 December 1992 | accessdate=22 May 2010}} Philip has stated that he has thought of himself as Danish, and his family spoke English, French, and German. Philip, who in his youth was known for his charm, was linked to a number of women including [[Osla Benning]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/0/romances-young-prince-philip/|title=The romances of young Prince Philip|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|first=Philip|last=Eade|date=5 May 2017|accessdate=10 August 2018}} ==Youth== ===Education=== [[File:G House from the South Lawn on an Autumn Afternoon.jpg|thumb|Philip studied at [[Gordonstoun]] School, Scotland.]] Philip was first educated at The Elms,{{cite book|last1=Boothroyd|first1=Basil|title=Prince Philip: An Informal Biography|date=1971|publisher=McCall Publishing Company|location=New York|isbn=0841501165|edition=First American}} an American school in Paris run by Donald MacJannet, who described Philip as a "know it all smarty person, but always remarkably polite".Alexandra, p. 42; Heald, p. 34. Fellow pupils at the school included [[Queen Anne of Romania|Princess Anne of Bourbon]], who later married King [[Michael of Romania]]. In 1928, he was sent to the United Kingdom to attend [[Cheam School]], living with his maternal grandmother, [[Victoria Mountbatten, Dowager Marchioness of Milford Haven]], at [[Kensington Palace]] and his uncle, [[George Mountbatten, 2nd Marquess of Milford Haven]], at Lynden Manor in [[Bray, Berkshire]].Heald, pp. 35–39 In the next three years, his four sisters married German noblemen and moved to Germany, his mother was placed in an asylum after being diagnosed with [[schizophrenia]],Brandreth, p. 66; Vickers, p. 205 and his father took up residence in [[Monte Carlo]].Eade, p. 104 Philip had little contact with his mother for the remainder of his childhood.Brandreth, p. 67 In 1933, he was sent to [[Schule Schloss Salem]] in Germany, which had the "advantage of saving school fees" because it was owned by the family of his brother-in-law, [[Berthold, Margrave of Baden]].Prince Philip quoted in Brandreth, p. 72 With the rise of [[Nazism]] in Germany, Salem's Jewish founder, [[Kurt Hahn]], fled persecution and founded [[Gordonstoun]] School in Scotland. After two terms at Salem, Philip moved to Gordonstoun.Brandreth, p. 72; Heald, p. 42 In 1937, his sister [[Princess Cecilie of Greece and Denmark|Cecilie]], her husband [[Georg Donatus, Hereditary Grand Duke of Hesse]], her two young sons, [[Prince Ludwig of Hesse and by Rhine|Ludwig]] and [[Prince Alexander of Hesse and by Rhine (1933–1937)|Alexander]], her newborn infant and her mother-in-law, [[Princess Eleonore of Solms-Hohensolms-Lich]], were killed in [[Sabena OO-AUB Ostend crash|an air crash at Ostend]]; Philip, then sixteen years old, attended the funeral in [[Darmstadt]].Brandreth, p. 69; Vickers, p. 273 The following year, his uncle and guardian Lord Milford Haven died of [[bone marrow cancer]].Brandreth, pp. 77, 136 ===Naval and wartime service=== After leaving Gordonstoun in early 1939, Philip enrolled as a cadet at the [[Britannia Royal Naval College|Royal Naval College, Dartmouth]], until he was [[repatriate]]d to Greece, living with his mother in Athens for a month in mid-1939 when, at the behest of the Greek king, [[George II of Greece|George II]], he returned to Britain in September to resume training for the [[Royal Navy]].Eade, pp. 129–130; Vickers, pp. 284–285, 433 He graduated from Dartmouth the next year as the best cadet in his course.{{citation|url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/ThecurrentRoyalFamily/TheDukeofEdinburgh/Navalcareer.aspx |title=Naval career |publisher=Official website of the British Monarchy |accessdate=7 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529132154/http://www.royal.gov.uk/ThecurrentRoyalFamily/TheDukeofEdinburgh/Navalcareer.aspx |archivedate=29 May 2010 }} During the Second World War, he continued to serve in the British forces, while two of his brothers-in-law, [[Prince Christoph of Hesse]] and [[Berthold, Margrave of Baden]], fought on the opposing German side.Vickers, pp. 293–295 Philip was appointed as a [[midshipman]] in January 1940. He spent four months on the battleship [[HMS Ramillies (07)|HMS ''Ramillies'']], protecting convoys of the Australian Expeditionary Force in the Indian Ocean, followed by shorter postings on [[HMS Kent (54)|HMS ''Kent'']], on [[HMS Shropshire (73)|HMS ''Shropshire'']] and in Ceylon (now [[Sri Lanka]]).Eade, pp. 132–133 After the [[Greco-Italian War|invasion of Greece by Italy]] in October 1940, he was transferred from the Indian Ocean to the battleship {{HMS|Valiant|1914|6}} in the [[Mediterranean Fleet (United Kingdom)|Mediterranean Fleet]].Heald, p. 60 [[File:HMS Valiant-2.jpg|thumb|left|alt=HMS Valiant|Philip served aboard [[HMS Valiant (1914)|HMS ''Valiant'']] in the [[Battle of the Mediterranean]].]] On 1 February 1941,{{London Gazette |issue=35455|date=13 February 1942 |page=715 |supp=|nolink=y}} he was commissioned as a [[sub-lieutenant]] after a series of courses at [[Portsmouth]], in which he gained the top grade in four out of five sections of the qualifying examination.Brandreth, p. 154; Heald, p. 66 Among other engagements, he was involved in the [[Battle of Crete]], and was [[mentioned in dispatches]] for his service during the [[Battle of Cape Matapan]], in which he controlled the battleship's searchlights. He was also awarded the [[Greek War Cross]] of Valour. Duties of lesser glory included stoking the boilers of the troop transport ship [[RMS Empress of Russia (1913)|RMS ''Empress of Russia'']].{{citation| url=http://www.unithistories.com/officers/RNR_officersM.html| title=Royal Naval Reserve (RNR) officers 1939–1945 – M| publisher=Unithistories.com| accessdate=12 October 2008}} In June 1942, he was appointed to the [[V and W-class destroyer]] and [[flotilla leader]] [[Thornycroft type leader|HMS ''Wallace'']], which was involved in convoy escort tasks on the east coast of Britain, as well as the [[Allied invasion of Sicily]].{{citation| last=Smith| first=David| title=Prince Philip's war heroics come to light after 60 years| newspaper=The Guardian|date=28 December 2003| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2003/dec/28/monarchy.davidsmith| accessdate=12 October 2008 | location=London}} Promotion to [[Lieutenant (Royal Navy)|lieutenant]] followed on 16 July 1942.{{London Gazette |issue=35664|date=11 August 1942 |page=3510 |supp=|nolink=y}} In October of the same year, he became first lieutenant of HMS ''Wallace'', at 21 years old one of the youngest first lieutenants in the Royal Navy. During the invasion of Sicily, in July 1943, as second in command of HMS ''Wallace'', he saved his ship from a night bomber attack. He devised a plan to launch a raft with smoke floats that successfully distracted the bombers, allowing the ship to slip away unnoticed. In 1944, he moved on to the new destroyer, [[HMS Whelp (R37)|HMS ''Whelp'']], where he saw service with the [[British Pacific Fleet]] in the 27th Destroyer Flotilla.Brandreth, pp. 155–163; Heald, pp. 66–67{{citation |url=http://www.naval-history.net/xGM-Chrono-10DD-63W-Whelp.htm| title=HMS Whelp, destroyer| publisher=Naval-history.net| accessdate=12 October 2008}} He was present in [[Tokyo Bay]] when the instrument of [[Surrender of Japan|Japanese surrender]] was signed. In January 1946, Philip returned to the United Kingdom on the ''Whelp'', and was posted as an instructor at [[HMS Royal Arthur (shore establishment)|HMS ''Royal Arthur'']], the Petty Officers' School in [[Corsham]], Wiltshire.Brandreth, p. 176 ==Marriage== [[Image:Royal Monogram of Prince Philip of Great Britain.svg|thumb|100px|Philip's monogram]] {{further|Wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Philip Mountbatten}} In 1939, [[George VI|King George VI]] and [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother|Queen Elizabeth]] toured the [[Britannia Royal Naval College|Royal Naval College, Dartmouth]]. During the visit, the Queen and Earl Mountbatten asked Philip to escort the King's two daughters, [[Elizabeth II|Elizabeth]] and [[Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon|Margaret]], who were Philip's [[Royal descendants of Queen Victoria and King Christian IX#Monarchs descended from Queen Victoria|third cousins]] through [[Queen Victoria]], and [[Royal descendants of Queen Victoria and King Christian IX#Monarchs descended from King Christian IX|second cousins once removed]] through [[King Christian IX of Denmark]].[[Alexandra of Yugoslavia|Queen Alexandra of Yugoslavia]] quoted in Heald, p. 57 Elizabeth fell in love with Philip and they began to exchange letters when she was thirteen.Brandreth, pp. 132–136, 166–168 Eventually, in the summer of 1946, Philip asked the King for his daughter's hand in marriage. The King granted his request, provided that any formal engagement be delayed until Elizabeth's twenty-first birthday the following April.Brandreth, p. 183 By March 1947, Philip had abandoned his Greek and Danish royal titles, had adopted the surname [[Mountbatten family|Mountbatten]] from his mother's family, and had become a naturalised British subject. The engagement was announced to the public on 10 July 1947.Heald, p. 77 Though Philip appeared "always to have regarded himself as an Anglican",''The Times'', 10 July 1947, p. 4 and he had attended Anglican services with his classmates and relations in England and throughout his Royal Navy days, he had been baptised in the Greek Orthodox Church. The [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], [[Geoffrey Fisher]], wanted to "regularise" Philip's position by officially receiving him into the Church of England,{{cite book|author=Boothroyd, Basil|authorlink=Basil Boothroyd|year=1971|title=Prince Philip: An Informal Biography|publisher=McCall|isbn=0841501165|pages=45–47}} which he did in October 1947.[https://www.nytimes.com/1947/10/04/archives/elizabeths-fiance-now-an-anglican.html "Elizabeth's Fiance Now an Anglican"] ''[[The New York Times]]'', 4 October 1947 The day preceding his wedding, King George VI bestowed the [[Style (manner of address)|style]] of ''[[Royal Highness]]'' on Philip and, on the morning of the wedding, 20 November 1947, he was made the [[Duke of Edinburgh]], [[Earl of Merioneth]], and [[Baron Greenwich]] of Greenwich in the County of London.{{London Gazette|issue=38128|pages=5495–5496|date=21 November 1947}} Consequently, being already a [[Knight of the Garter]], between 19 and 20 November 1947 he bore the unusual style His Royal Highness Sir Philip Mountbatten and is so described in the Letters Patent of 20 November 1947. Philip and Elizabeth were married in a ceremony at [[Westminster Abbey]], recorded and broadcast by [[BBC]] radio to 200 million people around the world.Heald, p. 86 However, in post-war Britain, it was not acceptable for any of the Duke of Edinburgh's German relations to be invited to the wedding, including Philip's three surviving sisters, all of whom had married German princes, some with [[Nazi Party|Nazi]] connections. After their marriage, the Duke and Duchess of Edinburgh took up residence at [[Clarence House]]. Their first two children were born: [[Prince Charles]] in 1948 and [[Princess Anne]] in 1950. Their marriage is now the longest of any British sovereign.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/7101094.stm|title=Queen celebrates diamond wedding|date=19 November 2007|accessdate=10 February 2017|publisher=BBC News}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/queen-elizabeth-II/9689130/Queen-and-Duke-of-Edinburgh-celebrate-65th-wedding-anniversary.html|title=Queen and Duke of Edinburgh celebrate 65th wedding anniversary|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=19 November 2012|accessdate=10 February 2017|first=Gordon|last=Rayner}} Philip was introduced to the [[House of Lords]] on 21 July 1948,{{cite web|url=https://api.parliament.uk/historic-hansard/lords/1948/jul/21/hrh-the-duke-of-edinburgh|title=HRH The Duke of Edinburgh (Lords Sitting of 21 July 1948)|publisher=UK Parliament|accessdate=31 October 2018}} immediately before his uncle [[Earl Mountbatten of Burma]].{{cite web|url=https://api.parliament.uk/historic-hansard/lords/1948/jul/21/earl-mountbatten-of-burma|title=Earl Mountbatten of Burma (Lords Sitting of 21 July 1948)|publisher=UK Parliament|accessdate=31 October 2018}} Philip, like his sons Charles and Andrew and other royals, ceased to be members of the House of Lords following the [[House of Lords Act 1999]]. He never spoke in the House. After his honeymoon at the Mountbatten family home, [[Broadlands]], Philip returned to the navy at first in a desk job at [[the Admiralty]], and later on a staff course at the [[Royal Naval College (Greenwich)|Naval Staff College, Greenwich]].Alexandra, pp. 100, 105–106 From 1949, he was stationed in [[Malta]] (residing at [[Villa Guardamangia]]) after being posted as the first lieutenant of the destroyer [[HMS Chequers (R61)|HMS ''Chequers'']], the lead ship of the 1st Destroyer Flotilla in the Mediterranean Fleet.Heald, p. 94 On 16 July 1950, he was promoted to [[Lieutenant commander (Royal Navy)|lieutenant commander]] and given command of the frigate [[HMS Magpie (U82)|HMS ''Magpie'']].Heald, p. 95{{London Gazette|issue=38994 |supp=y|page=4152|date=15 August 1950}} On 30 June 1952, Philip was promoted to [[Commander (Royal Navy)|commander]],{{London Gazette|issue=39597 |supp=|page=3821|date=15 July 1952}} though his active naval career had ended in July 1951.{{citation|url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/ThecurrentRoyalFamily/TheDukeofEdinburgh/Militaryinvolvement.aspx |title=The Duke of Edinburgh > Military involvement |publisher=Official website of the British Monarchy |accessdate=7 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528151405/http://www.royal.gov.uk/ThecurrentRoyalFamily/TheDukeofEdinburgh/Militaryinvolvement.aspx |archivedate=28 May 2010 }}Heald, p. 97 With the King in ill health, Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh were both appointed to the [[Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council|Privy Council]] on 4 November 1951, after a coast-to-coast tour of [[Canada]]. At the end of January 1952, Philip and his wife set out on a tour of the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]]. On 6 February 1952, when they were in [[Kenya Colony|Kenya]], Elizabeth's father died and she became queen. It was Philip who broke the news of her father's death to Elizabeth at [[Sagana Lodge]], and the royal party immediately returned to the United Kingdom.Brandreth, pp. 245–247 ==Consort of the Queen== [[File:Elizabeth and Philip 1953.jpg|thumb|right|[[Coronation of Elizabeth II|Coronation]] portrait of Queen Elizabeth II with the Duke of Edinburgh, June 1953, by [[Cecil Beaton]]]] ===Royal house=== The accession of Elizabeth to the throne brought up the question of the name of the [[royal house]]. The Duke's uncle, [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma]], advocated the name ''House of Mountbatten'', as Elizabeth would typically have taken Philip's last name on marriage; however, when [[Mary of Teck|Queen Mary]], Elizabeth's grandmother, heard of this suggestion, she informed the British Prime Minister [[Winston Churchill]], who himself later advised the Queen to issue a royal proclamation declaring that the royal house was to remain known as the [[House of Windsor]]. Churchill's strong personal antipathy to Lord Mountbatten, whom he considered a dangerous and subversive rival who had lost India, may have contributed to this. Prince Philip privately complained, "I am nothing but a bloody amoeba. I am the only man in the country not allowed to give his name to his own children."Brandreth, pp. 253–254 On 8 February 1960, several years after the death of Queen Mary and the resignation of Churchill, the Queen issued an [[Order in Council]] declaring that ''[[Mountbatten-Windsor]]'' would be the surname of her and her husband's male-line descendants who are not styled as ''Royal Highness'' or titled as Prince or Princess.{{cite news| url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/41948/supplement/1003 | work=[[The London Gazette]]| title=Supplement to The London Gazette of Friday, 5th February 1960 | date=8 February 1960}} While it seems the Queen had "absolutely set her heart" on such a change and had it in mind for some time, it occurred only eleven days before the birth of [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York|Prince Andrew]] (19 February), and only after three months of protracted correspondence between constitutional expert [[Edward Iwi]] (who averred that, without such a change, the royal child would be born with "the Badge of Bastardy") and Prime Minister [[Harold Macmillan]] who had attempted to rebuff Iwi.Travis, Alan (18 February 1999). [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1999/feb/18/monarchy "Queen feared 'slur' on family", ''The Guardian'']. Retrieved 17 April 2014 After her accession to the throne, the Queen also announced that the Duke was to have "place, pre-eminence and precedence" next to her "on all occasions and in all meetings, except where otherwise provided by [[Act of Parliament]]". This meant the Duke took precedence over his son, the [[Prince of Wales]], except, officially, in the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|British parliament]]. In fact, however, he attends Parliament only when escorting the Queen for the annual [[State Opening of Parliament]], where he walks and sits beside her.British-Japanese Parliamentary Group. [https://www.webcitation.org/69OQnr5nU?url=http://www.bjpg.co.uk/publications/Tour_of_Parliament_(English).pdf Tour of the Palace of Westminster]. Retrieved 2012/5/2. Contrary to rumours over the years, the Queen and Duke are said by insiders to have had a strong relationship throughout their marriage, despite the challenges of Elizabeth's reign.{{cite news|title=Love and Majesty|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/society/2012/01/queen-elizabeth-201201|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date=January 2012}} The Queen referred to Prince Philip in a speech on the occasion of her Diamond Jubilee in 2012 as her "constant strength and guide".{{cite news|title=Prince Philip: The Man At The Queen's Side|date=5 June 2012|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2012-06-05/prince-philip-the-man-at-the-queens-side/|publisher=ITV}} ===Duties and milestones=== As consort to the Queen, Philip supported his wife in her new duties as sovereign, accompanying her to ceremonies such as the [[State Opening of Parliament]] in various countries, state dinners, and tours abroad. As Chairman of the [[Coronation of the British monarch|Coronation]] Commission, he was the first member of the royal family to fly in a helicopter, visiting the troops that were to take part in the ceremony.Brandreth, p. 259 Philip was not crowned in the service, but knelt before Elizabeth, with her hands enclosing his, and swore to be her "liege man of life and limb".Brandreth, p. 263 [[File:StateLibQld 1 204880 Greeting Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, during the royal visit in 1954.jpg|left|upright|thumb|The Duke of Edinburgh in [[Brisbane]], Australia, in 1954]] In the early 1950s, his sister-in-law, [[Princess Margaret]], considered marrying a divorced older man, [[Peter Townsend (RAF officer)|Peter Townsend]]. The press accused Philip of being hostile to the match, to which he replied "I haven't done anything." Philip had not interfered, preferring to stay out of other people's love lives.Brandreth, p. 270 Eventually, Margaret and Townsend parted. For six months, over 1953–54, Philip and Elizabeth toured the Commonwealth; again their children were left in the United Kingdom.Brandreth, p. 278 In 1956, the Duke, with [[Kurt Hahn]], founded [[The Duke of Edinburgh's Award]] in order to give young people "a sense of responsibility to themselves and their communities". In the same year, he also established the [[Commonwealth Study Conference]]s. From 1956 to 1957, Philip travelled around the world aboard the newly commissioned [[HMY Britannia|HMY ''Britannia'']], during which he opened the [[1956 Summer Olympics]] in Melbourne and visited the [[Antarctica|Antarctic]], becoming the first royal to cross the [[Antarctic Circle]].{{cite web|last1=Nikkhah|first1=Roya|title=Prince Philip: The Duke you don't know|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/theroyalfamily/8273569/Prince-Philip-the-Duke-you-dont-know.html|website=The Telegraph (UK)|accessdate=12 December 2017}} The Queen and the children remained in the UK. On the return leg of the journey, Philip's private secretary, [[Michael Parker (courtier)|Mike Parker]], was sued for divorce by his wife. As with Townsend, the press still portrayed divorce as a scandal and eventually Parker resigned. He later said that the Duke was very supportive and "the Queen was wonderful throughout. She regarded divorce as a sadness, not a hanging offence."Quoted in Brandreth, p. 287 In a public show of support, the Queen created Parker a Commander of the [[Royal Victorian Order]].Brandreth, pp. 287, 289 Further press reports claimed that the Queen and the Duke were drifting apart, which enraged the Duke and dismayed the Queen, who issued a strongly worded denial.Brandreth, p. 288 On 22 February 1957, she granted her husband the style and title of a Prince of the United Kingdom by [[Letters Patent]], and it was gazetted that he was to be known as "His Royal Highness The Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh".{{London Gazette |issue= 41009|date= 22 February 1957|page=1209}} Philip was appointed to the [[Queen's Privy Council for Canada]] on 14 October 1957, taking his [[Oath of Allegiance (Canada)|Oath of Allegiance]] before the Queen in person at her Canadian residence, [[Rideau Hall]].{{Citation|last=Bousfield|first=Arthur| author2=Toffoli, Gary| title=Fifty Years the Queen| publisher=Dundurn Press| year=2002|location=Toronto|page=12| url=https://books.google.com/?id=w8l5reK7NjoC&printsec=frontcover&q=|isbn=1-55002-360-8}} Remarks he made two years later to the [[Canadian Medical Association]] on the subject of youth and sport were taken as a suggestion that Canadian children were out of shape. This was at first considered "tactless", but Philip was later admired for his encouragement of physical fitness.{{citation| url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/prince-philip-hrh-the-duke-of-edinburgh/| title=Prince Philip (HRH The Duke of Edinburgh)| work=The Canadian Encyclopedia| publisher=Historica Canada| accessdate=23 June 2017}} In Canada in 1969, Philip spoke about his views on republicanism: {{Quote|It is a complete misconception to imagine that the monarchy exists in the interests of the monarch. It doesn't. It exists in the interests of the people. If at any time any nation decides that the system is unacceptable, then it is up to them to change it.Brandreth, p. 50}} [[File:Prins Philip (1982).jpg|thumb|left|Philip at the opening of the World Championship Coach-and-fours in 1982]] Philip is [[Patronage|patron]] of some 800 organisations, particularly focused on the environment, industry, sport, and education. He was President of the [[National Playing Fields Association]] (now known as [[Fields in Trust]]) for 64 years, from 1947 until his grandson [[Prince William]] took over the role in 2013.{{cite news|title=Prince William succeeds the Duke of Edinburgh as he gives up royal role|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/royal/390492/Prince-William-succeeds-the-Duke-of-Edinburgh-as-he-gives-up-royal-role|accessdate=7 December 2016|work=Daily Express|date=9 April 2013}} He served as UK President of the [[World Wildlife Fund]] from 1961 to 1982, International President from 1981, and President Emeritus from 1996. In 1952, he became patron of The Industrial Society (since renamed [[The Work Foundation]]). He was President of the [[International Equestrian Federation]] from 1964 to 1986,{{cite web|title=Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, Talks Love of and Involvement in Combined Driving|url=https://www.usequestrian.org/media/press-releases/prince-philip-duke-of-edinburgh-talks-love-of-involvement-in-combined-driving-in-first-post-retirement-interview-at-royal-windsor-horse-show|website=US Equestrian|publisher=US Equestrian Communications Department|accessdate=12 December 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171212152435/https://www.usequestrian.org/media/press-releases/prince-philip-duke-of-edinburgh-talks-love-of-involvement-in-combined-driving-in-first-post-retirement-interview-at-royal-windsor-horse-show|archivedate=12 December 2017|df=dmy-all}} and has served as Chancellor of the Universities of Cambridge, [[University of Edinburgh|Edinburgh]], [[University of Salford|Salford]], and [[University of Wales|Wales]].{{citation|url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/ThecurrentRoyalFamily/TheDukeofEdinburgh/Activitiesandinterests.aspx |title=The Duke of Edinburgh: Activities and interests |publisher=Official website of the British Monarchy |accessdate=19 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106114941/http://www.royal.gov.uk/ThecurrentRoyalFamily/TheDukeofEdinburgh/Activitiesandinterests.aspx |archivedate=6 November 2011 }} In 2017, the [[British Heart Foundation]] thanked Prince Philip for being its patron for 55 years, during which time, in addition to organising fundraisers, he "supported the creation of nine BHF-funded centres of excellence".{{cite web|title=Our Chief Executive thanks Prince Philip for his commitment as Patron|url=https://www.bhf.org.uk/news-from-the-bhf/news-archive/2017/may/our-chief-executive-thanks-prince-philip-for-his-work-as-patron|website=News Archive|publisher=British Heart Foundation|accessdate=30 December 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171230024120/https://www.bhf.org.uk/news-from-the-bhf/news-archive/2017/may/our-chief-executive-thanks-prince-philip-for-his-work-as-patron|archivedate=30 December 2017|df=dmy-all}} He is an Honorary Fellow of [[St Edmund's College, Cambridge]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.st-edmunds.cam.ac.uk/people/hrh-prince-philip-duke-edinburgh|title=St Edmund's College – University of Cambridge|website=www.st-edmunds.cam.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-09-10}} At the beginning of 1981, Philip wrote to his eldest son, Charles, counselling him to make up his mind to either propose to [[Lady Diana Spencer]] or break off their courtship.Brandreth, p. 344; Lacey, p. 276 Charles felt pressured by his father to make a decision and did so, proposing to Diana in February.Brandreth, p. 346; Lacey, pp. 277–278 [[Wedding of Charles, Prince of Wales, and Lady Diana Spencer|They married]] six months later. [[File:Duke of Edinburgh 33 Allan Warren.jpg|thumb|upright|Photograph by [[Allan Warren]], 1992]] By 1992, the marriage of the Prince and Princess of Wales had broken down. The Queen and Philip hosted a meeting between Charles and Diana, trying to effect a reconciliation, but without success.Brandreth, pp. 348–349 Philip wrote to Diana, expressing his disappointment at both Charles's and her extra-marital affairs, and asking her to examine both his and her behaviour from the other's point of view.Brandreth, pp. 349–351 She found the letters hard to take, but nevertheless she appreciated that he was acting with good intent.Brandreth, pp. 351–353 Charles and Diana separated and later divorced. A year after the divorce, [[Death of Diana, Princess of Wales|Diana was killed in a car crash]] in Paris on 31 August 1997. At the time, the Duke was on holiday at Balmoral with the extended royal family. In their grief, Diana's two sons, Princes [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|William]] and [[Prince Harry|Harry]], wanted to attend church and so their grandparents took them that morning.Brandreth, p. 358 For five days, the Queen and the Duke shielded their grandsons from the ensuing press interest by keeping them at Balmoral, where they could grieve in private. The royal family's seclusion caused public dismay, but the public mood changed after a live broadcast made by the Queen on 5 September.Brandreth, p. 359 Uncertain as to whether they should walk behind her coffin during the [[Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales|funeral procession]], Diana's sons hesitated. Philip told William, "If you don't walk, I think you'll regret it later. If I walk, will you walk with me?" On the day of the funeral, Philip, William, Harry, Charles and Diana's brother, [[Charles Spencer, 9th Earl Spencer|Earl Spencer]], walked through London behind her bier. Over the next few years, [[Mohamed Fayed]], whose son [[Dodi Fayed]] was also killed in the crash, claimed that Prince Philip had ordered the death of Diana and that the accident was staged. The inquest into the Princess of Wales's death concluded in 2008 that there was no evidence of a conspiracy.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7322204.stm |publisher=BBC News | title=Duke 'did not order Diana death' | date=31 March 2008 | accessdate=22 May 2010}} Prince Philip receives a Parliamentary annuity (of £359,000 since 1990{{#tag:ref|The amount was set by the Civil List (Increase of Financial Provision) Order 1990. It was initially set at £40,000 in the Civil List Act 1952, raised to £65,000 by the Civil List Act 1972, and raised to £165,000 by the Civil List (Increase of Financial Provision) Order 1984.|group=fn}}) that serves to meet official expenses in carrying out public duties. The annuity is unaffected by the reform of royal finances under the [[Sovereign Grant Act 2011]].{{cite web|title=Royal Public Finances |url=https://www.royal.gov.uk/pdf/Introduction%20to%20Head%20of%20State%20expenditure%202006-07.pdf |accessdate=7 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224234303/https://www.royal.gov.uk/pdf/Introduction%20to%20Head%20of%20State%20expenditure%202006-07.pdf |archivedate=24 February 2014 }}"Living off the State, A critical guide to UK Royal Finance", Jon Temple, 2nd edition 2012 Any part of the allowance that is not used to meet official expenditure is liable for tax. In practice, the entire allowance is used to fund his official duties.{{cite news|title=Sovereign grant Act 2011: Tax|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sovereign-grant-act-2011-guidance/sovereign-grant-act-2011-guidance#tax|accessdate=7 August 2014|publisher=www.gov.uk}} During [[Golden Jubilee of Elizabeth II|his wife's Golden Jubilee]] in 2002, the Duke was commended by the [[Speaker of the House of Commons (United Kingdom)|Speaker of the British House of Commons]] for his role in supporting the Queen during her reign. The Duke of Edinburgh's time as royal consort exceeds that of any other consort in British history;{{cite news|title=Prince Philip reaches milestone|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8005464.stm|accessdate=7 June 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=18 April 2009}} however, [[Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother]] (his mother-in-law), who died aged 101, has had the longest lifespan to date. In April 2008, Philip was admitted to [[King Edward VII's Hospital]] for "assessment and treatment" for a chest infection, though he walked into the hospital unaided and recovered quickly,{{citation| title=Duke of Edinburgh is in hospital|publisher=BBC News| date=4 April 2008| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7333280.stm| accessdate=12 October 2008}} and was discharged three days later to recuperate at [[Windsor Castle]].{{citation| title=Prince discharged from hospital|publisher=BBC News| date=6 April 2008| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7330697.stm| accessdate=12 October 2008}} In August, the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' reported that he was suffering from [[prostate cancer]]. Buckingham Palace, which usually refuses to comment on rumours of ill health, claimed that the report was an invasion of privacy and issued a statement denying the story.{{citation|title=Statement From Buckingham Palace Following the Evening Standard's Story Entitled 'Prince Philip Defies Cancer Scare' |publisher=Buckingham Palace |date=6 August 2008 |url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Pressreleases/2008/STATEMENTFROMBUCKINGHAMPALACEFOLLOWINGTHEEVENINGST.aspx |accessdate=20 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202213153/http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Pressreleases/2008/STATEMENTFROMBUCKINGHAMPALACEFOLLOWINGTHEEVENINGST.aspx |archivedate=2 December 2010 }} The newspaper retracted the report and admitted it was untrue.{{citation|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/2008/08/08/british-paper-retracts-story-claiming-prince-philip-has-prostate-cancer/|title=British Paper Retracts Story Claiming Prince Philip Has Prostate Cancer|publisher=Fox News|date=8 August 2008}}{{citation|url=http://news.smh.com.au/world/paper-apologises-for-prince-philip-story-20080808-3sea.html|title=Paper apologises for Prince Philip story|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=8 August 2008}} In June 2011, in an interview marking his 90th birthday he said that he would now slow down and reduce his duties, stating that he had "done [his] bit".{{citation| title=Prince Philip turns 90 and vows to 'slow down'|publisher=BBC News| date=10 June 2011| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13722857| accessdate=11 June 2011}} His wife, the Queen, gave him the title [[Lord High Admiral (United Kingdom)|Lord High Admiral]] for his 90th birthday.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-13730067 |title=New title for Duke of Edinburgh as he turns 90 |publisher=BBC News |date=10 June 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}} While staying at the royal residence at Sandringham, Norfolk, on 23 December 2011, the Duke suffered chest pains and was taken to the cardio-thoracic unit at [[Papworth Hospital]], Cambridgeshire, where he underwent successful [[Percutaneous coronary intervention|coronary angioplasty]] and [[Coronary stent|stenting]].{{citation|author=Peter Hunt |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-16323794 |title=Prince Philip has heart procedure at Papworth Hospital |publisher=BBC News|date=24 December 2011 |accessdate=24 December 2011}} He was discharged on 27 December.{{citation|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-16337357|title=Duke of Edinburgh leaves hospital|publisher=BBC News|date=27 December 2011|accessdate=27 December 2011}} [[File:HM The Queen and Prince Philip.JPG|thumb|The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh on the balcony of [[Buckingham Palace]], June 2012]] On 4 June 2012, during the [[Diamond Jubilee of Elizabeth II|celebrations]] in honour of his wife's [[Diamond Jubilee]], Philip was taken from Windsor Castle to the [[King Edward VII's Hospital Sister Agnes|King Edward VII Hospital]], London, suffering from a bladder infection.{{cite web|url=http://www.itn.co.uk/home/46928/Duke+of+Edinburgh+hospitalised|title=Duke of Edinburgh hospitalised|date=4 June 2012|accessdate=5 June 2012|publisher=[[ITN]]}}{{dead link|date=November 2016}}{{cite news|title=Prince Philip in hospital and to miss Diamond Jubilee concert|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18325522|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=4 June 2012|date=4 June 2012}} He was released from hospital on 9 June.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/09/world/europe/uk-prince-philip/index.html?hpt=hp_t2|title=Britain's Prince Philip released from hospital in time for his birthday|publisher=CNN|date=9 June 2012}} After a recurrence of infection in August 2012, while staying at [[Balmoral Castle]], he was admitted to [[Aberdeen Royal Infirmary]] for five nights as a precautionary measure.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-19317991|title=Prince Philip leaves Aberdeen hospital after five nights|publisher=BBC News|date=20 August 2012}} In June 2013, Philip was admitted to the [[London Clinic]] for an [[Exploratory surgery|exploratory operation]] on his abdomen, spending 11 days in hospital.{{cite news|title=Prince Philip leaves hospital, will recuperate at Windsor Castle|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/06/17/world/europe/uk-prince-philip-hospital/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=17 June 2013|date=17 June 2013}} On 21 May 2014, the Prince appeared in public with a bandage on his right hand after a "minor procedure" was performed in Buckingham Palace the preceding day.{{cite news|title=Duke of Edinburgh has 'minor procedure' on hand|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-27507555|accessdate=7 August 2014|publisher=BBC News|date=21 May 2014}} In June 2017, he was taken from Windsor to London and admitted to King Edward VII Hospital after being diagnosed with an infection.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/06/21/duke-edinburgh-admitted-hospital-infection/|title=Prince Philip admitted to hospital with infection and misses State Opening of Parliament|work=The Daily Telegraph|first=Hannah|last=Furness|date=21 June 2017|accessdate=12 November 2017}} He spent two nights in the hospital and was unable to attend the State Opening of Parliament and Royal Ascot.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/jun/21/prince-philip-admitted-to-hospital-with-infection|title=Prince Philip to spend second night in hospital|work=The Guardian|first=Caroline|last=Davies|date=21 June 2017|accessdate=12 November 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/06/22/europe/prince-philip-discharged-hospital/index.html|title=UK's Prince Philip discharged from hospital after treatment for infection|publisher=CNN|first=Eliza|last=Mackintosh|date=22 June 2017|accessdate=12 November 2017}} ===Retirement and beyond=== Prince Philip retired from his royal duties on 2 August 2017, meeting Royal Marines in his final solo public engagement, aged 96. Since 1952 he had completed 22,219 solo engagements. Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] thanked him, via [[Twitter]], for "a remarkable lifetime of service".{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/prince-philip-prepares-for-final-royal-engagement-10970314|title=Prince Philip carries out final royal engagement before retirement|date=2 August 2017|publisher=Sky News}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-40798469|title=Prince Philip carries out final official engagement|publisher=BBC News|date=2 August 2017}} On 20 November 2017, he celebrated his 70th wedding anniversary with the Queen, which made her the first British monarch to celebrate a platinum wedding anniversary.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2017/nov/20/queen-prince-philip-portraits-platinum-wedding-70th-anniversary|title=Queen and Prince Philip portraits released to mark 70th anniversary|date=20 November 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=20 November 2017}} On 3 April 2018, Philip was admitted to the King Edward VII Hospital for a planned [[hip replacement]], which took place the next day. This came after the Duke missed the annual Maundy and Easter Sunday services. On 12 April his daughter, Princess Anne, spent about 50 minutes in the hospital and afterwards said her father was "on good form". He was discharged the following day.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-43755269|title=Duke of Edinburgh leaves hospital|date=13 April 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=13 April 2018}} On 19 May, six weeks later, he attended the [[Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle|wedding]] of his grandson Prince Harry to actress [[Meghan Markle]] and was able to walk with the Queen unaided.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/topics/cpwpy79d6dxt/royal-wedding-2018|title=Royal Wedding 2018|website=BBC News|accessdate=23 May 2018}} In October that year, he accompanied the Queen to the [[Wedding of Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank|wedding]] of their granddaughter [[Princess Eugenie]] to [[Jack Brooksbank]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/in-pictures-45829410|title=Princess Eugenie wedding in pictures: Splendid hats and gusts of wind|publisher=BBC News|date=12 October 2018}} with ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reporting that Philip works on a "wake up and see how I feel" basis when deciding whether to attend an event or not.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/royal-family/2018/10/09/duke-edinburgh-will-decide-day-attends-royal-wedding/|title=Duke of Edinburgh 'will decide at last moment' whether he attends royal wedding of Princess Eugenie|work=The Daily Telegraph|first=Camilla|last=Tominey|date=9 October 2018|accessdate=11 November 2018}} ==Personality and image== Philip played [[polo]] until 1971, when he started to compete in [[Combined driving|carriage driving]], a sport which he helped expand; the early rule book was drafted under his supervision.Heald, pp. 212–214 He was a keen yachtsman, striking up a friendship in 1949 with [[Uffa Fox]] in [[Cowes]]. He and the Queen regularly attended [[Cowes Week]] in [[HMY Britannia|HMY ''Britannia'']]. His first airborne flying lesson took place in 1952; by his 70th birthday he had accrued 5,150 pilot hours.Heald, pp. 148–149 He was presented with [[Royal Air Force]] wings in 1953.{{cite web|last=Monarchy |first=British |url=https://www.royal.gov.uk/MonarchUK/ArmedForces/TheRoyalAirForce.aspx |title=The Royal Air Force |work=Official website of the British Monarchy |accessdate=6 May 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617152205/http://www.royal.gov.uk/MonarchUK/ArmedForces/TheRoyalAirForce.aspx |archivedate=17 June 2013 }} In April 2014, it was reported that an old [[British Pathe]] newsreel film had been discovered of Philip's 1962 two-month flying tour of [[South America]]. Filmed sitting alongside Philip at the aircraft's controls was his co-pilot [[Family of Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge|Captain Peter Middleton]], the grandfather of the Duke's granddaughter-in-law, [[Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge]].{{cite web|last=Sparkes|first=Matthew|title=Royal couples' grandparents' jet-age meeting|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/news/10779536/Pictured-Royal-couples-grandparents-jet-age-meeting.html|work=Daily Telegraph|date=22 April 2014|accessdate=7 May 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Tominey|first1=Camilla|title=Truth behind Prince George's love of aviation|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/royal/643885/Truth-behind-Prince-George-love-aviation|location=UK |work=Daily Express |date=14 February 2016|accessdate=19 February 2015|quote=It (the photograph) shows the Duchess of Cambridge's grandfather, Captain Peter Middleton, with Prince Philip in 1962...}} [[File:Her Majesty the Queen at Breakfast.jpg|thumb|left|''Her Majesty the Queen at Breakfast'' painted by her husband in 1957. Biographer [[Robert Lacey]] described the painting as "a tender portrayal, impressionistic in style, with brushstrokes that are charmingly soft and fuzzy".Lacey, p. 368]] He has painted with oils, and collected artworks, including contemporary [[cartoon]]s, which hang at Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, Sandringham House, and Balmoral Castle. [[Hugh Casson]] described Philip's own artwork as "exactly what you'd expect ... totally direct, no hanging about. Strong colours, vigorous brushstrokes."Heald, p. 253 His down-to-earth manner was attested to by a White House butler who recalled that, on a visit in 1979, Philip had engaged him and a fellow butler in a conversation, and poured them drinks.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jan/18/obama-inauguration|location=London |newspaper=The Guardian| first=Christopher|last=Goodwin|title=I'm tickled to death. I never thought I'd see such a thing|date=18 January 2009}} As well as a reputation for bluntness and plain speaking,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-13682432|title=Prince Philip at 90 on a lifetime of speaking his mind|publisher=BBC News|access-date=2016-04-22}} Philip is noted for occasionally making observations and jokes that have been construed as either funny, or as gaffes: awkward, [[Political correctness|politically incorrect]] or even offensive, but sometimes perceived as stereotypical of someone of his age and background.{{citation|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/5360412.stm |title=Caught on tape: Infamous gaffes|publisher=BBC News|date= 19 September 2006|accessdate=12 October 2008}}{{citation|url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,23599,23745347-5007146,00.html |title=Prince Philip right to have a dig at Durie |publisher=News.com.au |author=Tim Blair |date=23 May 2008 |accessdate=12 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108233956/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C23599%2C23745347-5007146%2C00.html |archivedate=8 January 2009 |df= }}{{citation|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2006/s1660067.htm |title=AM – Prince Philip reminded of blunders on his 85th birthday |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=12 October 2008}}{{citation|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4156/is_20000423/ai_n13948104 |title=The Ssecret Life of Prince Philip |newspaper=Sunday Herald |date=23 April 2000 |accessdate=12 October 2008 |first=Stephen |last=Naysmith |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206001454/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4156/is_20000423/ai_n13948104 |archivedate=6 December 2008 |df= }}{{citation|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/05/05/AR2007050500981_pf.html|title=Prince Philip Has a Mouthful Of a Title. And, Often, His Foot|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=12 October 2008|first=Paul|last=Duggan}} In an address to the General Dental Council in 1960, he jokingly coined a new word for his blunders: "Dontopedalogy is the science of opening your mouth and putting your foot in it, a science which I have practised for a good many years."Dolby, Karen ''The Wicked Wit of Queen Elizabeth II'', Michael O'Mara Books, London 2015, p44 Later in life he suggested his comments may have contributed to the perception that he is "a cantankerous old sod".Prince Philip quoted in Brandreth, p. 7 The historian [[David Starkey]] has described him as a kind of "HRH [[Victor Meldrew]]".Starkey, speaking on BBC News Radio Four, 10 June 2011 For example, in May 1999 British newspapers accused Philip of insulting deaf children at a pop concert in Wales by saying, "No wonder you are deaf listening to this row."Brandreth, p. 46 Later Philip wrote, "The story is largely invention. It so happens that my mother was quite seriously deaf and I have been Patron of the Royal National Institute for the Deaf for ages, so it's hardly likely that I would do any such thing."Letter of 4 June 1999 quoted in Brandreth, p. 46 When he and the Queen met Stephen Menary, an army cadet blinded by an IRA bomb, and the Queen enquired how much sight he retained, Philip quipped: "Not a lot, judging by the tie he's wearing." Menary later said: "I think he just tries to put people at ease by trying to make a joke. I certainly didn't take any offence."{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/theroyalfamily/6805975/Duke-of-Edinburgh-gaffes-by-mocking-blind-boy.html|title=Duke of Edinburgh gaffes by mocking blind boy|last=Leach|first=By Ben|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2016-04-22}} During a state visit to the People's Republic of China in 1986, in a private conversation with British students from [[Xi'an]]'s [[Northwest University (China)|North West University]], Philip joked, "If you stay here much longer, you'll go slit-eyed."Heald, pp. 244–245; Lacey, p. 303 The British press reported on the remark as indicative of racial intolerance, but the Chinese authorities were reportedly unconcerned. Chinese students studying in the UK, an official explained, were often told in jest not to stay away too long, lest they go "round-eyed".Lacey, p. 304; see also Heald, p. 245 for a Hong Kong version of the "round-eyed" joke. His comment had no effect on [[China–United Kingdom relations|Sino-British relations]], but it shaped his own reputation.Heald, p. 246; Lacey, p. 304 ==Titles, styles, honours and arms== {{Main|List of titles and honours of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh}} [[File:Prince Philip as Colonel-in-Chief of the Royal Canadian Regiment.jpg|thumb|The Duke of Edinburgh, [[Colonel-in-Chief]] of the [[Royal Canadian Regiment]], presenting the 3rd Battalion with their Regimental Colours in April 2013]] Philip has held a number of titles throughout his life. Originally holding the title and style of a [[prince of Greece and Denmark]], Philip abandoned these royal titles prior to his marriage, and was thereafter created a British [[duke]], among other noble titles. The Queen formally issued letters patent in 1957 making Philip a [[British prince]]. When addressing the Duke of Edinburgh, as with any male member of the royal family except the monarch, the rules of etiquette are to address him the first time as ''Your Royal Highness'', and thereafter as ''Sir''.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101112125544/http://www.debretts.com/etiquette/british-behaviour/r-to-s/royalty.aspx|title=Royalty – Debrett's Guide to British Behaviour|date=12 November 2010|publisher=|accessdate=23 May 2018}} ===Honours and honorary military appointments=== The Duke of Edinburgh was appointed by King George VI to the [[Order of the Garter]] on 19 November 1947, the eve of his wedding. Since then, Philip has received 17 different appointments and decorations in the Commonwealth, and 48 from foreign states. The inhabitants of some villages on the island of [[Tanna (island)|Tanna, Vanuatu]] [[Prince Philip Movement|worship Prince Philip as a god]]; the islanders possess portraits of the Duke and hold feasts on his birthday.{{citation|last=Squires|first=Nick|title=Is Prince Philip an island god?|publisher=BBC News|date=10 June 2007|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/6734469.stm|accessdate=12 October 2008|location=London, UK}} [[File:Yaohnanen Tribesmen Show Pictures of 2007 Visit with Prince Philip.jpg|thumb|left|[[Ni-Vanuatu]] with pictures of Philip]] Upon his wife's accession to the throne in 1952, the Duke was appointed Admiral of the [[Sea Cadet Corps (United Kingdom)|Sea Cadet Corps]], [[Colonel-in-Chief]] of the British [[Army Cadet Force]], and [[Air Commodore-in-Chief]] of the [[Air Training Corps]].Heald, p. 111 The following year, he was appointed to the equivalent positions in Canada, and made [[Admiral of the Fleet (Royal Navy)|Admiral of the Fleet]], [[Captain General Royal Marines]], [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]], and [[Marshal of the Royal Air Force]] in the United Kingdom.Heald, pp. 264–267 Subsequent military appointments were made in [[New Zealand]] and [[Australia]].Brandreth, pp. 407–408; Heald, pp. 264–267 In 1975, he was appointed [[Colonel]] of the [[Grenadier Guards]], a position he handed over to his son Andrew in 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.royal.uk/duke-york-appointed-colonel-grenadier-guards|title=The Duke of York is appointed Colonel of the Grenadier Guards|publisher=Royal Household|date=1 December 2017}} On 16 December 2015, his role as Honorary Air Commodore-in-Chief was handed over to the Duchess of Cambridge. To celebrate his 90th birthday, the Queen appointed him [[Lord High Admiral (United Kingdom)|Lord High Admiral]] of the [[Royal Navy]] (the highest title in the organisation){{cite web|url=https://www.royal.uk/duke-edinburgh-appointed-lord-high-admiral|title=The Duke of Edinburgh appointed Lord High Admiral|publisher=royal.uk|date=10 June 2011|accessdate=4 June 2016}} and Canada appointed him to the highest ranks available in all three branches of the [[Canadian Armed Forces]].{{cite web|url=http://news.gc.ca/web/article-en.do?nid=605239|last=Office of the Prime Minister of Canada|title=PM announces the appointment of His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh to the highest ranks of the Canadian Armed Forces|date=10 June 2011|publisher=Queen's Printer for Canada|accessdate=10 June 2011}} On their 70th wedding anniversary, 20 November 2017, the Queen appointed him Knight Grand Cross (GCVO) of the [[Royal Victorian Order]], making him the first British national since his late uncle, the first [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Earl Mountbatten of Burma]], to be entitled to wear the breast stars of four orders of chivalry in the United Kingdom.{{cite news|last1=Furness|first1=Hannah|title=Queen grants new honour to Prince Philip for 70th wedding anniversary|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/11/20/queen-grants-new-honour-prince-philip-70th-wedding-anniversary/|accessdate=22 November 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=20 November 2017}} ===Arms=== {{Infobox COA wide |image = Coat of Arms of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.svg |bannerimage = Royal Standard of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.svg |badgeimage = |notes = Following his marriage to Princess Elizabeth until 1949, Prince Philip's arms featured a differenced version of the [[royal coat of arms of the United Kingdom]], derived from his ancestor [[Princess Alice of the United Kingdom|Princess Alice]].
Unlike the arms used by other members of the royal family, the Duke's arms no longer features the royal arms of the United Kingdom, as he was granted new arms by King George VI in 1949. However, they do feature elements representing Greece and Denmark, from which he is descended in the male line; the [[Battenberg family|Mountbatten family]] arms, from which he is descended in the female line; and the City of [[Edinburgh]]. |year_adopted = 19 November 1947 |escutcheon = '''From 1949:'''

Divorced 30 May 1996 | rowspan="2" | [[Sarah Ferguson]] | [[Princess Beatrice of York]] | {{N/A|None}} |- | [[Princess Eugenie]] | {{N/A|None}} |- ! rowspan="2" scope="row" | [[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex]] | rowspan="2" | 10 March 1964 | rowspan="2" | 19 June 1999 | rowspan="2" | [[Sophie Rhys-Jones]] | [[Lady Louise Windsor]] | {{N/A|None}} |- | [[James, Viscount Severn]] | {{N/A|None}} |} ==Ancestry== Philip is a great-grandson of [[Christian IX of Denmark]], and as such belongs in male line to the Danish [[House of Glücksburg]], originally a [[cadet branch]] of the [[House of Oldenburg]], which held several thrones and provided consorts to rulers of Russia and Great Britain in the 19th and 20th centuries. In 1993, scientists were able to confirm the identity of the remains of several members of [[Empress Alexandra of Russia]]'s family, more than seventy years after their [[execution of the Romanov family|massacre in 1918]], by comparing their [[mitochondrial DNA]] to living [[matrilineal]] relatives, including Prince Philip, her maternal grandnephew. Philip, Alexandra and her children are all descended from [[Princess Alice of the United Kingdom]], the daughter of [[Queen Victoria]], through a purely female line.{{cite journal |last1=Gill |first1=Peter |last2=Ivanov |first2=Pavel L. |last3=Kimpton |first3=Colin |last4=Piercy |first4=Romelle |last5=Benson |first5=Nicola |last6=Tully |first6=Gillian |last7=Evett |first7=Ian |last8=Hagelberg |first8=Erika |last9=Sullivan |first9=Kevin |date=February 1994 |title=Identification of the remains of the Romanov family by DNA analysis |journal=Nature Genetics |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=130–135 |doi=10.1038/ng0294-130 |pmid=8162066 }} {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes|align=center |ref={{cite book |last=Louda |first=Jiří |last2=Maclagan |first2=Michael |authorlink2=Michael Maclagan |year=1999 |origyear=1981 |title=Lines of Succession: Heraldry of the Royal Families of Europe |edition=2nd |location=London |publisher=Little, Brown |isbn=978-0-316-84820-6 |page=34 }} |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |1= 1. '''Religion in Cheshire''', and, in particular, Christianity, has a long history. In the 2001 census, however 1 in 5 people either were recorded as no religion or religion not stated.<ref name=CCC>{{cite web|url=http://www.cheshire.gov.uk/equalityanddiversity/religionandethnicityfactsandfigures.htm |title=Religious Group Breakdown |work=Cheshire County Council |accessdate=2008-06-29 |date=2007-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060716050531/http://www.cheshire.gov.uk/equalityanddiversity/religionandethnicityfactsandfigures.htm |archivedate=July 16, 2006 }}</ref> The boundary of the [[Church of England]] [[Diocese of Chester]] currently follows most closely the pre-1974 county boundary of Cheshire, so it includes all of [[Wirral Peninsula|Wirral]], most of [[Stockport]], and the Cheshire panhandle, that included [[Tintwistle Rural District]] council area.<ref>[http://www.chester.anglican.org/diocese/ Chester Diocese (Church of England).] ''Official website''. Retrieval Date: 30 September 2007.</ref> In terms of [[Roman Catholic]] church administration, the majority of Cheshire falls into the Roman Catholic [[Diocese of Shrewsbury]].<ref>[http://www.dioceseofshrewsbury.org/index.asp Diocese of Shrewsbury (Roman Catholic).] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100729184948/http://www.dioceseofshrewsbury.org/index.asp |date=2010-07-29 }} ''Official website''. Retrieval Date: 30 September 2007.</ref> Cheshire still has a slightly higher proportion of Christians than the rest of the North West of England.<ref name=CCC/>
There is an [[Islamic]] organisation in Cheshire called '''Islamic Forum Cheshire''' it is affiliated to the [[Muslim Council of Britain]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcb.org.uk/affiliates.php |title=MCB Affiliates |accessdate=2008-06-28 |work= |publisher=www.mcb.org.uk |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080628043059/http://www.mcb.org.uk/affiliates.php |archivedate=2008-06-28 |df= }}</ref>
In Cheshire there were number of [[Jewish]] congregations some of which were set up by [[World War II]] evacuees <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishgen.org/JCR-UK/england_geographic.htm#cheshire |title= Cheshire |accessdate=2008-06-28 |work= |publisher=www.jewishgen.org |date= }}</ref> the only remaining is [[Chester Hebrew Congregation]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishgen.org/JCR-UK/Community/chester/index.htm |title=Chester Hebrew Congregation |accessdate=2008-06-28 |work= |publisher=www.jewishgen.org |date= }}</ref> In Cheshire there is also a Jewish [[Primary School]] called [[North Cheshire Jewish Primary School]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ncjps.org.uk/prospectus.htm |title=Prospectus |accessdate=2008-06-28 |work= |publisher=www.ncjps.org.uk |date= |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080414194005/http://www.ncjps.org.uk/prospectus.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-04-14}}</ref>
There are a number of [[Buddhist]] centres in Cheshire, including Kagyu Buddhism Cheshire,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dechen.org/centres/northwest/cheshire.html |title=Kagyu Buddhism Cheshire |accessdate=2008-06-28 |work= |publisher=www.dechen.org |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070806204757/http://www.dechen.org/centres/northwest/cheshire.html |archivedate=2007-08-06 |df= }}</ref> and Odiyana Buddhist Meditation Centre which provides classes in Buddhism throughout the County.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.meditationincheshire.org/ |title=Odiyana Buddhist Meditation Centre |accessdate=2008-06-28 |work= |publisher=www.meditationincheshire.org |date= }}</ref>
In [[Warrington]] there is a [[Sikh]] [[Gurdwara]] called [http://www.sikhtemplewarrington.org Guru Nanak Gurdwara Sikh Temple] built by the [[India]]n community in Cheshire.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allaboutsikhs.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2418 |title=Gurudwaras in United Kingdom |accessdate=2008-06-28 |work= |publisher= |date= }}</ref>

The dominant Church is the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]] although traces of a forming [[Montenegrin Orthodox Church]] are present. ==Distribution== The results of the Montenegrin census of 2011 by ethnic groups, the latest census in which the indication of identification (whether by confession or as irreligious) in the question for confession was obligatory, are as follows: {|class="wikitable" |+ |-bgcolor="#e0e0e0" ! rowspan="2"|Ethnic groups

Adherents of Orthodox Christianity in Montenegro are predominantly [[Montenegrins (ethnic group)|Montenegrins]] and [[Serbs]]. Ethnic Serbs in Montenegro are adherents of the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]] and its dioceses in Montenegro: [[Metropolitanate of Montenegro and the Littoral]], [[Eparchy of Budimlja and Nikšić]] and [[Eparchy of Mileševa]]. Ethnic Montenegrins are divided between the Serbian Orthodox Church and the [[Montenegrin Orthodox Church]] (which is still in its phase of conceivement and is non-canonical and unrecognized). The current Metropolitan bishop is [[Amfilohije Radović]]. He is a vocal supporter of Russia and has repeatedly denounced NATO; calling its actions similar to that of the Ottoman Empire and that the organization is a "national fascist pact."Milica Minić. "A Serbian priest in anti-NATO campaign" [http://www.cdm.me/english/a-serbian-priest-in-anti-nato-campaign-they-want-to-have-a-catholic-priest-a-hodja-and-a-rabbi-among ''CDM'' 17 Aug. 2016] == Islam == {{main|Islam in Montenegro}} [[File:Pljevlja City-center Mosque.JPG|thumb|250px|[[Husein-paša's Mosque]] in [[Pljevlja]]]] [[Muslims]] form the largest minority religion in the country. Montenegro's 118,477 Muslims make up 19.11% of the total population. Muslims in Montenegro are divided into two main groups, and further subgroups: *[[Muslim Slavs|Slavic]] Muslims **[[Bosnian language|Bosnian-speaking]] ethnic [[Bosniak]] Muslims **[[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin-speaking]] ethnic [[Montenegrins (ethnic group)|Montenegrin Muslims]] **Other Slavic Muslims ([[Muslims by nationality]]), including [[Gorani people|Gorani]], and other Slavs of the Muslim faith who identify by religion rather than by ethnicity. *[[Albanians|Albanian]] Muslims **[[Albanian language|Albanian-speaking]] ethnic [[Albanians|Albanian]] Muslims Islam is the dominant religion in the northeastern municipalities, which are part of the [[Sandžak]] geographical region, and in municipalities where Albanians form a majority. Islam is the majority religion in [[Rožaje]], [[Plav, Montenegro|Plav]], [[Gusinje]], [[Ulcinj]] and [[Petnjica]]. == Catholic Church == {{main|Catholic Church in Montenegro}} [[File:Marktplatz Kotor 2014.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Kotor Cathedral|St. Tryphon's Cathedral]] in [[Kotor]]]] Catholic Christianity is mostly present in the region of [[Boka Kotorska]], where there is a significant presence of ethnic [[Croats]]. Also, a number of ethnic [[Albanians]] are adherents of Catholic Christianity. According to [http://www.cnewacanada.ca/ecc-bodypg-ca.aspx?eccpageID=73&IndexView=toc CNEWA Canada] Catholics of the [[Byzantine Rite]] number over 20 000 persons in the regions of Montenegro and Serbia: In 2003 an Apostolic Exarchate was created for [[Eastern Catholicism|Greek Catholics]] in Serbia and Montenegro, headed by Bishop Djura Džudžar (born 1954, appointed 2003). It has 21 parishes and 22,720 faithful, consisting mostly of a group of ethnic Rusyn Greek Catholics in the region of Vojvodina.http://www.cnewacanada.ca/ecc-bodypg-ca.aspx?eccpageID=73&IndexView=toc == Judaism == {{Main|History of the Jews in Montenegro}} In February 2012, the Montenegrin Prime Minister [[Igor Lukšić]] signed an agreement with the Montenegrin Jewish community to grant official recognition of Jews as a minority in Montenegro. The agreement also established [[Judaism]] as the country's fourth official religion, along with the Catholic Church, Eastern Orthodox Christianity, and Islam.{{cite web|url=http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/Montenegro.html |title=Jewish history of Montenegro |publisher=[[Jewish Virtual Library]] |accessdate=2012-11-16}} == Atheism == The majority of Montenegro's population, 98.69%, declares to belong to a religion, though observance of their declared religion may vary widely. On the census from 2011, atheists, those who declared no religion, comprised about 1.24% of the whole population, and agnostics 0.07%. Religiosity is lowest in the [[Bay of Kotor]] region and the capital city of [[Podgorica]]. Municipalities with highest share of atheists are [[Herceg Novi]] (2.43%), [[Kotor]] (2.03%), [[Podgorica]] (1.99%) and [[Tivat]] (1.7%). In contrast, [[Rožaje]] has the fewest atheists, who make up only 0.01% of its population. In some municipalities more than half of population are undeclared, however. ==See also== *[[Demographics of Montenegro]] *[[Orthodoxy in Montenegro]] *[[Catholic Church in Montenegro]] *[[Protestantism in Montenegro]] *[[Islam in Montenegro]] *[[History of the Jews in Montenegro]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Sources == * {{Cite book|ref=harv|last=Živković|first=Tibor|authorlink=Tibor Živković|year=2012|title=De conversione Croatorum et Serborum: A Lost Source|location=Belgrade|publisher=The Institute of History, Čigoja štampa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rZEimQEACAAJ}} * {{Cite journal|ref=harv|last=Živković|first=Tibor|authorlink=Tibor Živković|title=On the Baptism of the Serbs and Croats in the Time of Basil I (867–886)|journal=Studia Slavica et Balcanica Petropolitana|year=2013|issue=1|pages=33-53|url=http://slavica-petropolitana.spbu.ru/files/2013_1/Zivkovic.pdf}} {{Montenegro topics |collapsed}} {{Religion in Europe}} [[Category:Religion in Montenegro]] [[Category:Christianity in Montenegro]] [[Category:Eastern Orthodoxy in Montenegro]] [[Category:Catholicism in Montenegro]] [[Category:Islam in Montenegro]] [[Category:Atheism in Montenegro]]

A '''religious community''' is a [[community]] (group of people) who practice the same [[religion]]. The term is used in a wider sense and a different narrower sense. People who define themselves as having a particular religion are considered to be members of the religion's community.
In the wider sense, the term is used to refer to members of one religion who may live in groups, or near or intermingled with members of other religions. Community members may mix with others in everyday life, but worship separately, typically in a dedicated [[temple]] such as a [[church (building)|church]] or [[mosque]]. One might speak of the Catholic community of [[Belfast]] (a city), or the Jewish community of France (a country). In other cases, a person must be formally accepted by community authorities to become acknowledged as a member. In Israel only couples both from the same officially recognized religious community [[marriage in Israel|may marry]].
The term is also used in a different, narrower sense to mean a group of people of the same religion living together specifically for religious purposes, often subject to formal commitments such as [[religious vows]], as in a [[monastery]].<ref name="Deegan"/>
== Types of Christian Communities ==
=== Order === Orders are Institutes in which solemn vows are made by at least some of the members. All members of these orders are called regulars, and if they are women they are called nuns ("moniales"). Additionally, Orders are typically dated in history as older than Congregations.
=== Congregations === A group of people assembled for religious worship. The Catholic [[Congregation (Catholic)|congregation]] in the Roman Curia is the most notable congregation.
=== Clerical === These Christian [[Institutes of the Christian Religion|institutes]], in accordance with the intentions of the Founder or by reason of legitimate tradition, are governed by [[Clergy|clerics]], assume the exercise of sacred Orders, and are recognized by the Church as clerical Institutes.
=== Lay === Lay, also known as lay affiliates or associates, play an important part in a religious community. Men and women who take part, formally, in a religious community, to make their mission and spirituality, and have great influence on the like of the community are known as lay affiliates. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://anunslife.org/blog/nun-talk/the-role-of-lay-associates-in-religious-life}}</ref>
=== Canons Regular === Canons regular === Monastic Orders ===
=== Mendicant Orders ===
=== Clerks Regular ===
=== Clerical Religious Congregations ===
=== Lay Religious Congregations ===
Lay religious communities include groups such as the Hutterites, [[Bruderhof Communities|Bruderhof]]<ref>{{Citation|last=Bruderhof|title=Bruderhof - Why Community|date=2012-01-11|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7pBrSi5jld8|accessdate=2017-05-25}}</ref>, Amish and some Mennonite churches. Some of these communities are tightly-bound, such as the Bruderhof<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsmax.com/FastFeatures/bruderhof-christians-beliefs-set/2015/05/07/id/643320/|title=5 Beliefs That Set the Bruderhof Apart From Other Christians|work=Newsmax|access-date=2017-06-12}}</ref> and Hutterites<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/hutterites/|title=Hutterites|last=Ryan|first=John|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|access-date=2017-06-12|language=en}}</ref>. The Amish and similar groups tend to be more loosely formed, but still act in a communal way. All of these communities will claim to be Christ-centred.
